conclusion: To determine the number of moments when the speed of the particle is 5 m/s, we need to analyze the displacement-time graph provided.
The graph shows displacement x on the vertical axis and time t on the horizontal axis.
The displacement starts at x = 10 m at t = 0 and decreases to x = -10 m at t = 4 s.
Velocity is the derivative of displacement with respect to time, v(t) = dx/dt.
Speed is the absolute value of velocity, |v(t)|.
The graph is a curve, indicating that the velocity is not constant.
The slope of the tangent to the curve at any point gives the velocity at that point.
We need to find the points where the slope of the tangent (velocity) is ±5 m/s.
The graph appears to be a quadratic curve, suggesting a parabolic motion.
Assume the displacement function is quadratic: x(t) = at^2 + bt + c.
The initial condition at t = 0 is x(0) = 10, so c = 10.
The final condition at t = 4 is x(4) = -10.
The velocity function is the derivative: v(t) = d/dt(at^2 + bt + 10) = 2at + b.
We need to solve |2at + b| = 5.
This gives two equations: 2at + b = 5 and 2at + b = -5.
Solve 2at + b = 5 for t.
Solve 2at + b = -5 for t.
Each solution to these equations represents a moment when the speed is 5 m/s.
Since the graph is symmetric and parabolic, there will be two solutions for each equation within the interval 0 ≤ t ≤ 4.
There are two moments when the speed is 5 m/s and two moments when the speed is -5 m/s.
Therefore, there are a total of four moments when the speed is 5 m/s.
